content.description: Just to the left of Pillow Fight. Fun lead on thinner gear. Stem between two seams following good holds. Transition into the thin crack on the right jamming your way up and exiting right.Considering this is at the Forks I imagine this has been climbed before? Anyone have any information on it?
content.location: Between pillow stuffing and pillow fight.Just left of Pillow fight, using the two seams.

content.description: Beautiful hand crack.  Getting through the pod can be the crux for some people.
content.protection: Gold camalots (#2) primarily, also takes blue.
content.location: First route to the right of Davidson Dihedral.

content.description:
From a distance, the route looks like you need Valley Giants or Big Bros to protect it safely.  But, there is a second, smaller crack in the corner that takes gear quite nicely. 

  A good route if you want to work on your wide crack technique.  Some loose blocks at the top.
content.protection: The left crack is could take gear up to 5 or 6 camalot, while the right crack is much smaller.
content.location: The obvious right facing corner with split by an offwidth crack.

content.description: Pillow Fight is located in the middle of Pillow Wall, just left of Davidson Dihedral (a prominent left-facing dihedral you can't miss). Fun hand-sized jamming as the crack goes vertical and the crack squeezes down to tight-hands and off-fingers to exit at the top. Fun route!
content.protection: Cams from 1/2" up to #2 Camalot, bring along dupes in the mid-sizes.

content.description: Pillow Case is found sort of right-middle on the Pillow Wall, a pair of cracks in a left-facing corner system. I think most people usually start out in, and mostly climb the right crack, that starts as tight hands, and gradually widens out to fists as you approach the rim.
content.protection: Cams from #.50 Camalot to #4 Camalot, assuming you pro in the right crack only.

content.description: This is an interesting engaging route, and unusual climbing for the Forks. It's almost entirely face with thin, but adequate protection. Manuel Rangel found, cleaned, TR'd and equipped this pitch. A safe lead would not of been possible without his efforts. Hats off to Manny for finding this quality route which had been overlooked for so long. The climbing is challenging and enjoyable. There are some loose flakes about 30 ft up, but it's easy at that point. The upper face is a little licheny but still climbs well. One should feel comfortable leading above small wireds and cams. Begin in a corner to a bulge (1st pin), face to flakes then a little to the right. Climb up along the arete (2nd pin) then face climb on the right side of the arete to the top.
content.protection: 2-3 sets of cams gray-blue metolious and one #3 camelot which can be placed in the initial corner. Also, small to medium nuts. Offsets are useful. Bring extra nuts in the thinner sizes. There are 2 fixed pins.
content.location: This route is all the way left of the Pillow Wall where the ground drops down and the cliff gets taller. It starts in an obtuse corner with an overhang 25 ft up. It can be recognized as a prominent pillar with a very flat top. There is a Ponderosa behind it which leans steeply away from the edge of the canyon.

content.description: Bouldery climbing using a few good locks and face holds leads to a fist-sized slot, then easier climbing above. Good climbing, but short lived.
content.protection: medium off set wires and smallest cams you have (tcu 00 wouldnt go to waste)- #2
content.location: This is the thin crack in between Ivory Snow and Crack-a-Pogo

content.description: Ivory Snow is the first splitter crack right of Pillow Case. The start is hard, consisting of fingers with OK feet, then grows to thin hands. Once past the first 20' the moves start to flow. When the angle eases off the crack pinches down and face moves put you near the top. Finish on a broken crack to the canyon rim.
content.protection: A few StoppersTCU's with doubles of Yellow Metolius Size.4- #2 Camalot

content.description: Located between Pillow Talk and Pillow Case, Geekus climbs a flaring crack that grows from fingers to thin hands to good hands at the top.  Fun from start to finish!
content.protection: A few Stoppers (Just 8' up the route there is the world's best stopper placement.)   .5 - #2 Camalot

content.description:
Davidson Dihedral is the aesthetic open book directly across from the Davidson Wall.  It is the line to do on the Pillow Wall and supposedly received it's name before it was climbed, because local climbers thought that Paul Davidson was the only one who could lead it. He wanted to call it "Pillowing", but Davidson Dihedral stuck. 

  The route is mainly tight hands and fingers, but is quite pumpy because the crack is flaring and insecure.  Pro is solid, but not mindless to place, and this can add to the difficulty.
content.location: This clean dihedral sits sandwiched between Pillow Talk and Pillow Fight routes.

content.description:
Crack-a-Pogo is located on the right end of the Pillow Wall just beyond the fairly obvious Marilyn Chambers Crack. 

  Start off fingerlocks climbing in two crack systems.  Once able, move to the right hand crack and enjoy the thin hand and hand jams to the canyon rim.   

  I have also climbed the left crack which is enjoyable.  Good hand jams climb a sweet crack then careful moves past a little loose rock land you on top.
content.protection: Half Set Stopper   .5 - #3 Camalots with doubles of #1 and #2

content.description: Another Paradise Forks twin-cracks-in-a-corner route.  Fun jamming and stemming.  Shorter and easier than most other routes on this wall.  For added challenge, you can climb either the left or right side cracks as eliminates.
content.protection: The right crack is fist-plus, while the left is smaller.  Consequently, you can use a range of gear to protect the route.
content.location: Start at the right side of the Pillow Wall ledge, at the base of a corner with twin cracks. Chlorox is to the right of the small tree, and Geekus is to the left.

content.description: Pillow Wall is on the western side of the northern arm of the canyon. There are several moderate climbs here, making this one of the more popular spots in the canyon. During the hot summer months, Pillow Wall goes into shade in early afternoon.
